questions.text: In a patient post op complete laryngectomy, all of the below is advised/expected except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Super supraglottic swallow Super supraglottic swallow is not used in post laryngectomy rehabilitation . It is a swallowing manoeuvre that prevents aspiration of food by closing the airway before swallowing. So it is used in management of dysphagia.

Highyeild:

Supraglottic swallow is advised to protect the airway from aspiration. It is based on the concept of closing the airway before swallowing to prevent aspiration. Steps include: (1) Taking a deep breath, (2) Holding breath, (3) Holding breath while swallowing, (4) Cough voluntarily and immediately after swallowing (clearance of residual food/liquid) It is NOT used in rehab post laryngectomy. After a laryngectomy, the patient won’t be able to talk and communicate, which results in psychological, social and economic trauma. To overcome these various rehabilitation methods like esophageal speech, electronic larynx, tracheoesophageal prosthesis, etc are available.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION A- Polite yawning is a nasal airflow inducing manoeuvre; which is based on olfaction rehabilitation after laryngectomy. OPTION C- In TEP, a fistula is created in the thick wall separating the trachea and esophagus surgically. This can be done primarily, at the time of total laryngectomy, or secondarily at weeks or years after total laryngectomy. Several days after the puncturing of the tracheoesophageal wall, a one-way valve prosthesis is placed. It allows exhaled air from lungs to pass into the esophagus when the tracheostomy stoma is closed. This air enters the esophagus and escapes through the mouth during which it induces vibration of the pharyngoesophageal segment for sound production. OPTION D- Esophageal speech involves use of the vibration of esophageal sphincter and subsequent phonation.

questions.text: A 60 year old female comes with a history of discharge and nasal bleeding since 1 month, she also complains of weight loss and fatigue. Following is the CECT image. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma Nasopharyngeal cancer is a rare but aggressive tumor that grows in the upper throat behind the nose, near the base of the skull. It is most common in Southeast Asia, especially in southern China, where it is linked to the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) and certain dietary and genetic factors. It often causes symptoms such as nosebleeds, hearing loss, ear infections, headaches, and neck lumps, but these may be mistaken for other conditions It is diagnosed by examining the nasopharynx with a flexible scope, taking a biopsy, and doing imaging tests such as MRI or CT scan. Three types of standard treatment are used: Radiation therapy Chemotherapy Surgery

questions.text: Identify the anomaly given in image ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Superior turbinate pneumatization Superior turbinate pneumatisation can be seen as an anatomical variation of the lateral nasal wall . It can seen in the above image and identified by tracing the location of superior turbinate.

Highyeild:

Although pneumatization of the middle nasal turbinate has been occasionally reported, pneumatization of the superior and inferior turbinates are very rare finding. A pneumatized superior turbinate is a rare cause of headache. In these cases the superior turbinate is forced anteriorly and inferiorly at the area between the middle turbinate and the nasal septum, leading to intranasal mucosal contact. Nasal endoscopy alone, does not provide us with adequate information for this inaccessible area of the superior nasal cavity. A coronal computed tomography (CT) must be obtained to confirm the diagnosis. Endoscopic surgery may provide permanent relief of the headache.

questions.text: What is the treatment for bilateral external canal atresia?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bone anchored hearing aid Treatment of bilateral external canal atresia is Bone anchored hearing aid.

Highyeild:

INDICATIONS FOR BAHA: When air-conduction (AC) hearing aid cannot be used: Canal atresia, congenital malformation of ear not amenable to treatment. Chronic ear discharge, not amenable to treatment. Excessive feedback and discomfort from air-conduction hearing aid. Conductive or mixed hearing loss, e.g. otosclerosis and tympanosclerosis where surgery is contraindicated. Single-sided hearing loss.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- OPTION B- Piston is employed in stapedectomy surgery in otosclerosis. OPTION C- Cochlear implants are used in Bilateral severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss. OPTION D- Vestibular implants are not used here.

Extraedge:

BAHA has three components: (i) titanium fixture (ii) titanium abutment and (iii) sound processor . The titanium fixture is surgically embedded in the skull bone with abutment exposed outside the skin. The titanium fixture bonds with the surrounding tissue in a process called osseointegration.

questions.text: NG tube length is measured by?

options.label: A
options.text: Nose to ear lobule to xiphisternum

options.label: B
options.text: Mouth to ear lobule to xiphisternum

options.label: C
options.text: Nose to ear lobule to umbilicus

options.label: D
options.text: Mouth to ear lobule to umbilicus

questions.correct_answer: A. Nose to ear lobule to xiphisternum
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nose to ear lobule to xiphisternum Distance from the tip of the nose to earlobe to xiphisternum is commonly used to determine the length of nasogastric tube to be inserted.
